channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports
channel.description: The latest Form 5800.1 hazardous material reports submitted to the Department of Transportation and posted online by the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration.

item.title: Report E-2024070568
item.description:
Report E-2024070568

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-23
  • City: STEWARTVILLE
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one (1) gallon of material released from one (1) 275-gallon poly tote due to a puncture from a sharp object. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and containerized all cleanup debris. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070571
item.description:
Report E-2024070571

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-22
  • City: ROCKFORD
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately half a gallon (.5) of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to a puncture from a sharp object. The released material impacted the trailer floor. Dayton Freight deployed granular absorbents to the impacted area and gathered the spent material and containerized the recovered material, PPE and the damaged drum in to one (1) 65-gallon metal drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.description:
Report X-2024071769

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-20
  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ABF FREIGHT SYSTEM, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Austin Rechtermann, 003 Operations Supervisor, contacted Safety regarding a UN1814, Potassium Hydroxide Solution spill on the trailer floor. Austin advised while unloading trailer 504561 the spill was noticed. Austin stated the carton appeared to had been damaged in transit. Austin advised the spill is contained to the trailer floor. Austin stated he would send photos to Safety of the spill. Safety contacted Kim with Cura for remediation.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Caps appears to have come loose during transport. While unloading package from trailer it fell from the rollers. This caused (2) 1G plastic bottles to come open and leak inside trailer. QA was notified, removed package in red lined tote to Hazmat cage for further processing utilizing all proper PPE. (Gloves and Goggles)

  • Description: This package was brought to the QA cage by the van line manager because of a big wet area on the top and side of the package. We made sure to place this package in a lined hazmat tote and moved this to the hazmat cage.

item.title: Report X-2024071824
item.description:
Report X-2024071824

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-19
  • City: ANCHORAGE
  • State: AK
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AT THE UPS FACILITY IN ANCHORAGE, ALASKA, ONE GROUND TO ALASKA PACKAGE REQUIRED A REWRAP DUE TO BEING WET FROM RAINWATER. GROUND TO ALASKA IS A LOWER RATE OFFERED BUT THE PACKAGE MUST TRANSPORT IN THE AIR NETWORK. UPON INSPECTION OF THE CONTENTS DISCOVERED ONE INNER BOX MARKED CARTRIDGES, SMALL ARMS, UN0012, 1.4S WITH A GROUND LIMITED QUANTITY MARK. THIS BOX CONTAINS (25) INNER BOXES CONTAINING (20) FRONTIER 62 GR FULL METAL JACKET CARTRIDGES. THIS PACKAGE ALSO CONTAINS (7) 50 ROUND BOXES OF WINCHESTER 9MM 124 GRAIN FULL METAL JACKET CARTRIDGES AND (3) 550 ROUND BOXES OF RIMFIRE TARGET CARTRIDGES. THERE ARE NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER BOX.

item.title: Report X-2024071684
item.description:
Report X-2024071684

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-18
  • City: HONOLULU
  • State: HI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: X-RAY EXAMINATION OF ONE AIR PACKAGE FROM USA TO NEW ZEALAND REVEALED POSSIBLE ANOMALIES INCONSISTENT WITH THE INVOICE DESCRIPTION OF KEYBOARD. THE PACKAGE WAS FLAGGED FOR FURTHER EXAMINATION BY U.S. CUSTOMS AND BORDER PROTECTION (CBP) ANTI-TERRORISM/CONTRABAND ENFORCEMENT TEAM (ATCET) AIR HONOLULU OFFICERS. WHILE THE OFFICERS WERE ATTEMPTING TO OPEN THE KEYBOARD AN UKNOWN CHEMICAL REACTION OCCURRED WITHIN THE KEYBOARD. THE CENTER OF THE KEYBOARD BEGAN TO SMOKE, MELT AND BURN. THE PACKAGE WAS SHIPPED FROM CALIFORNIA USING UPS ACCOUNT Y85681, THE UPS STORE, 1191 HUNTINGTON DRIVE, DUARTE CA 91010. PER THE ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS - SECTION II OF IATA PACKING INSTRUCTION 967, NO DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ARE REQUIRED.

item.title: Report E-2024070550
item.description:
Report E-2024070550

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-18
  • City: DICKINSON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 16, 2024, a pallet of 1-gallon pails of paint related material tipped over during unloading and released approximately thirty (30) gallons of product to the pavement. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from E3 Environmental (E3) to remediate the impacted site. E3 personnel deployed granular absorbents and absorbent pads to the paint material impacted pavement and collected it with hand tools. All damaged product were containerized into eight (8) 55-gallon steel drums. Crews collected all spent absorbents and containerized them into three (3) 55-gallon steel drums for transport and disposal.

  • Description: 3 poly totes were received these totes were placed into the box sideways. the totes are as wide as they are long. When going to retrieve the 2nd tote the forklift operator pushed his forks in too far and forked the drum of cardinal bag that was behind the tote. In house cleanup wad used to clean up the spill. the spill was contained and managed correctly. no material went offsite. The root cause of the spill being that the totes were placed into the truck sideways this was communicated with the people who loaded the truck to not do that in future.

  • Description: On July 16, 2024, one (1) 275-gallon tote of UN1791 was punctured in transit and released approximately 100-gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Green Site Services (GSS) to remediate the impacted site. The crew containerized all impacted pallets into one (1) cubic yard box for disposal. GSS utilized absorbents and neutralizer to remediate the impacted site. All impacted materials were containerized in five (5) 55-gallon drums.

PLACED THE LEAKING PACKAGE INTO A SPILL TRAY, PLACED THE LEAKING HAZMAT ON SPILL CART, REMOVED ANY OTHER TAINTED PACKAGES, AND CLEANED THE SCENE ACCORDING TO HIS RESPONSE SHEET.

  • City: DALLAS
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On July 12, 2024, one (1) 5-gallon pail of paint was damaged and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Safety and Health Consulting Services (ES&H) to remediate the impacted site. ES&H personnel deployed granular absorbents to the paint-impacted dock and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and the damaged pail were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum to be staged onsite for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024070519
item.description:
Report E-2024070519

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-12
  • City: CHATTANOOGA
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On July 12, 2024, one (1) 330-gallon tote of sodium hydroxide was damaged by a load shift and released approximately 300-gallons of product to the trailer interior and concrete below. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE crews utilized neutralizer throughout the trailer and on the concrete below, then deployed granular absorbents to the trailer and concrete, working them in with hand tools. utilized a forklift to transfer the remaining contents in the damaged tote into new one. All sodium hydroxide-impacted material was collected and containerized in four (4) 55-gallon drums

item.title: Report X-2024071799
item.description:
Report X-2024071799

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-02
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 18000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On Tuesday, July 2, 2024, a CN mechanical performing an inspection observed that the bottom outlet valve appeared to be leaking from tank car # UTLX 210420 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Waterloo Yard Master who in turn notified the CN Dangerous Goods Team. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by a CN emergency response contractor. A CN emergency response contractor was dispatched to the location for mitigation. The contractor performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap. It was determined that there was a failure in the sealing surface of the valve seat to include a defective gasket. (The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight and the BOV in the closed position and pinned upon initial inspection). CN emergency response contractor did observe cable seal to be correctly in place. The BOV cap was removed, and it was observed to be leaking past the closed ball. The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The BOV cap was then removed and observed for 20 minutes to ensure there was no further leakage from the valve. It was noted that the BOV cap gasket was deformed and was replaced. The bottom outlet valve cap was then re-installed and tightened with a 36" pipe wrench. Upon tightening the BOV cap, CN emergency response contractor proceeded to place new cable seals on the BOV / Cap.

item.title: Report X-2024071685
item.description:
Report X-2024071685

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-23
  • City: Harahan
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 17700
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On 06-23-2024 a CN Mechanical employee detected a strong foul odor emanating from tank car # GLNX 23299 containing UN 1993/Crude Sulfate Turpentine/Class 3/PG II while performing work on the repair track at the CN Mays Yard in Harahan, LA. The employee notified his supervisor who in turn made notification to the CN Dangerous Goods Team that initiated a response. The on-duty CN Dangerous Goods Officer dispatched an emergency response contractor to the location to investigate. The responding contractor noted a strong odor upon arrival to the rail car's location. There were no visible liquid leaks observed. The inspection of the top fittings revealed the manway cover gasket protruding from the manway cover. A 4-gas meter with a PID sensor detected 16 PPM of VOC's at the sealing surface of the manway cover. The shipper security seal was found to be intact upon arrival. The manway cover security seal was removed, and the cover opened for the purpose of inspecting the gasket. The inspection revealed the gasket to be torn preventing a proper seal allowing the product vapors to escape. The gasket was replaced followed by the re-securement of the swing bolts. The area was tested again with the gas meter which was non-detect for VOC's. A replacement security seal was applied to the manway cover. The liquid and air valves within the protective housing were also inspected for proper securement prior to deeming the rail car safe for continued transportation. The rail car was released back to the transportation department for continued transportation to destination.

item.title: Report E-2024070523
item.description:
Report E-2024070523

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-18
  • City: HILLSBOROUGH
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ACV ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 3000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Tanker was parked over gravel/dirt portion of private property at our facility in Rahway, NJ. Lading was Waste Corrosive liquid, nos in a specification DOT-407 cargo tank constructed of stainles steel, which is an authorized package and compatible with the lading. Driver parked loaded tanker in our yard and didn't ensure the internal valve was fully closed before leaving. Blank flange cap on end of wet line had been recently replaced and mistakenly was replaced with an aluminum cap. Lading was leaking slowly through ajar internal valve into wet line and corroded aluminum blank flange cap from within. Corrosion to point of spillage and approx. 50 gallons of lading leaked onto the ground. Product was cleaned up and site remediated by in-house labor and materials. Mechanical repairs to trailer and subsequent testing underway as of this reporting.

item.title: Report I-2024070016
item.description:
Report I-2024070016

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-25T15:13:18+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-28
  • City: BENTONVILLE
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: REPUBLIC AIRWAYS HOLDINGS INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Passenger purchased gas generator at a Lowes in New Jersey on 5/27/2024 in an effort to use for disaster relief in Northwest Arkansas. She was under the impression that the unit was new because it was packaged that way and she had no reason to believe otherwise. There were no fumes or noticeable stains on the box. She presented it to the American Airlines ticket counter in PHL for her AA 4602/4342 PHL-LGA-XNA flights operated by Republic Airways, Inc. TSA scanned the item in PHL before being loaded on the aircraft and no dangerous goods were present. Ground crew in PHL loaded it on the aircraft. The unit shipped to LGA and no noticeable spills or fumes were observed by LGA ground crew and the package continued to XNA. Once in XNA ground crew noticed approximately 1 qt leaked on the cargo floor and some luggage. Republic Ops, Maintenance and Dangerous Goods were contacted immediately. On call maintenance contractors for Republic Airways were called out and cleaned the aircraft quickly with several cleaning agents. The extent of gasoline spilled on the cargo floor was minimal.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Driver noticed LNG was Ieaking from the rear cabinet of the MC-338 tanker after he stopped. Bystanders called 911 before the driver could. Farmville Fire Department arrived on scene and would not allow the driver to open the back doors of his transport tanker to determine the source of the leak or to prevent further Ieaking. Farmville FD contacted the state emergency hazmat team and waited for their response. Upon arrival, the state hazmat team noted that the leak had stopped and that there was no danger or threat and allowed the driver to open up the rear doors. The driver ascertained that the leak was coming from a flange to flange connection behind the discharge valve of the transport and waited for a company technician to arrive.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately fifteen (15) gallons of material released from one (1) 55-gallon metal drum due to falling freight that punctured the drum resulting in the released material impacting the trailer floor. Dayton Freight cleaned the impacted area and containerized the recovered clean-up material into one (1) 55-gallon metal drum. The damaged drum was overpacked. The generated waste was staged at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freight’s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-17
  • City: MARSHFIELD
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XSJ experienced a UN1993 Unisol Liquid Red BK 50 release from a 330-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1 cup of product released to a 1’ x 1’ area of the trailer floor and tote body due to a broken gasket. The crew retrieved a new gasket and repaired the tote for shipment on. The impacted areas were cleaned and wiped down with absorbent pads. All waste was placed into a 55-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • City: ALBANY

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: FORTY-SEVEN AIR PACKAGES EACH MARKED AND LABELED WITH CLASS 9 DIAMOND LABELS, UN1845, AND DRY ICE 2.5 KGS. THE PACKAGES CONTAINED FOOD PRODUCTS FROZEN WITH UN1977, NITROGEN, REFRIGERATED LIQUID, DIVISION 2.2 INSTEAD OF UN1845 DRY ICE, CLASS 9. THE PACKAGES WERE OFFERED AIR SERVICE BUT WERE DISCOVERED AT THE ORIGIN PICKUP FACILITY PRIOR TO AIRCRAFT CONTAINER SCANS. THESE PACKAGES HAVE NOT BEEN ACCEPTED FOR AIR OR TRANSPORTED IN THE AIR BY UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO. THE NITROGEN, REFRIGERATED LIQUID INSIDE EACH PACKAGE WAS NOT OFFERED IN A MANNER ASCERTAINABLE AT THE TIME OF ACCEPTANCE, THUS REPORTABLE UNDER 49CFR 175.31(B). THE PACKAGES WERE SHIPPED FROM OREGON USING UPS ACCOUNT JA1916, OREGON VALLEY FARM, 2280 THREE LAKES RD SE, ALBANY OREGON 97322.

  • Description: PART TIME METRO SUPERVISOR NOTICED LEAKING PACKAGE ON METRO 3. STOPPED BELT AND NOTIFIED RMP. RMP TOOK PACKAGE TO DMP. SUPERVISORS THEN NOTIFIED HAZMAT RESPONDER/AUDITOR WHO DONNED PPE AND INSPECTED PACKAGE IN SPILL TOTE AND IDENTIFIED THE CONTENTS. ONCE IT WAS DETERMINED THAT CONTENTS WERE HAZARDOUS AND NO IDENTIFYING MARKINGS WERE ON CARTON, CONTACTED THE HMSC UNDER THE CAPACITY OF A HAZMAT AUDITOR AND REPORTED IT AS AN UNDECLARED HAZMAT SHIPMENT.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: AN UNLOADER WAS UNLOADING ONE OF THE PACKAGE CARS AT OUR FACILITY AND HEARD RATTLING SOUND OF AEROSOL CANS WHILE HANLDING ONE OF THE PACKAGES. AN ACCEPTANCE AUDITOR WAS NOTIFIED AND THE PACKAGE WAS INSPSECTED. THE PACKAGE WAS FOUND TO CONTAIN AEROSOL CANS AND WAS PROCESSED AS AN UNDECLARED DANGEROUS GOODS SHIPMENT.

item.title: Report X-2024071491
item.description:
Report X-2024071491

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-07-09
  • City: PORTLAND
  • State: OR
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: RESPONDED TO CALL AT DOOR 37. DONNED FULL P.P.E. GOGGLES, APRON, GLOVES, SILVER SHIELD LINERS, BOOTS. UPON ENTERING THE TRAILER DISCOVERED LEAKING LIMITED QUANTITY PACKAGE ON FLOOR. FOR SAFETY MOVED UNDAMAGES AND UNSOILED PACKAGES OUT OF WAY. DISCOVERED A SEPARATE LEAKER IN THAT TIER. RESPONDED TO EACH CALL SEPARATELY PER DECISION-TREE AND APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEETS. CLEANED UP BOTH LEAKERS AND CONTAINERIZED EACH LEAKER SEPARATELY. BROUGHT BACK TO PSC FOR FURTHER PROCESSING. UPON OPENING ONE OF THE AFFECTED PACKAGES IN TIER DISCOVERED AEROSOL CANS WITH NO EXTERNAL MARKINGS INDICATING A LIMITED QUANTITY. ADVISED RMP WHO REVIEWED AND TOOK PHOTOS OF ALL SIDES, LABEL AND INSIDE. PROCESSING AS AN UNDECLARED PER DISCUSSION WITH RMP. RMP CONTACT HMSC TO REPORT UNDECLARED

item.title: Report E-2024070467
item.description:
Report E-2024070467

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-28
  • City: ABILENE
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 6500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal LAB. ERTS dispatched DSC Environmental to assist with cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 10-gallons of product released to a 7’ x 20’ area of the trailer floor and an 8’ x 6’ area of the concrete lot below due to a puncture. Absorbents were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The damaged drum, impacted absorbents, and cleanup debris were containerized into (2) 95-gallon poly drums. The waste was stored onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.title: Report E-2024070110
item.description:
Report E-2024070110

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: MARION
  • State: OH
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ESTES EXPRESS LINES
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: First Call was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 33ft-by-1ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that five (5) gallons of material was released due to crushed freight due to hard braking damaging twelve (12) plastic bottles. First Call personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted area and then used a granular absorbent to gather the neutralized material. The spent absorbents were containerized into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum and the damaged bottles were placed into one (1) 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was transported to the nearest ESTES terminal. The damaged bottles were then combined with the spent absorbents. The 55-gallon poly drum was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor’s demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report I-2024070014
item.description:
Report I-2024070014

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-24
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: PORT TERMINAL RAILROAD ASSOCIATION (INC)
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At approximately 06:09 AM on 06/24/24 I recieved notification that the tank car had sloshed product (Substituted Phenol) from under the manway. The car was located in track 47 at our North Yard, the shipper was contacted and they elected to use our Haz-Mat Contractor M&M Protection LLC to respond. Upon arrival it was noted that all 8 swing bolts were less than tool tight and the gasket was worn. These issues were corrected by M&M, new gasket, swing bolts tighten in a star pattern with no more evidence of product leaking. The car was washed and all spillage/residue was remediated.

item.description:
Report I-2024060047

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-22T18:15:45+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-29
  • City: SAN FRANCISCO
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Halfway through the flight, passenger 20A, told FA Pang that their laptop was emitting an electrical smell. FA conferred with FM and both agreed there was a smell. No flames, heat, or smoke were present. Out of an abundance of caution, the MacBook Pro was placed into the TCB. The TCB was placed in an aft lav and monitored occasionally per CA instructions occasionally throughout the flight. The TCB remained in the aft lav until descent, in which it was brought to the forward lav for easy access upon door opening. Due to no signs of fire, smoke, or heat, pax was escorted to the exit and was able to retrieve the laptop out of the TCB. FAs reminded to fill out IORs and thanked for erring on the side of caution.

item.title: Report I-2024060052
item.description:
Report I-2024060052

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-20T00:36:44+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-25
  • City: MILLINGTON
  • State: MD
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: EAST PENN LOGISTICS LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 166135
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: An East Penn Logistics, LLC driver was on Cypress Road Maryland, Rt 291, heading towards the Maryland / Delaware line. While checking in his mirrors he drifted right, went off the road into a ditch and tried to recover back onto the road and over corrected and ended in a roll over onto the driver's side. The driver was treated for minor injuries. The local Police responded to the scene. They called a local towing company to assist in the clean up and the towing of the truck. The Maryland Department of Environment also responded to the call. By the time they arrived, the incident was mostly cleaned up. They were happy with the clean up and no further action to be done via the MD EPA for clean up. The truck and batteries were towed back to Phillips Garage in Sudlersville, MD. The driver returned the next day to help repalletize and package the scrap batteries for shipping back to East Penn Manufacturing, Lyons Station for proper disposal of the batteries at our secondary lead smelter.

  • Description: The freight was not secured in the trailer coming from Pitt Ohio with a trailer seal on the door. As the trailer was moving to Ross/Auburn, MA terminal the freight shifted and 1 box of 6 boxes shift, broke open causing 4 cans to be damaged as cans of paint leaked in the trailer. The paint only leaked in the yard when the doors were opened. No paint reached any drains. Paint cleanup was performed after it was determined what the proper HM clean up procedure needed to be followed to protect Ross employees. A dock employee then took the damaged box of paint off the pallet in the trailer. The damaged- 1 box/4- 1 gallon cans and cleaning materials used for cleanup were placed in a recovery drum for disposal.

Crews deployed neutralizing, granular absorbents to the impacted trailer floor and asphalt and swept them up with hand tools.   • Description: On July 11, 2024, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3266 was punctured by a nail and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel deployed soda ash to the UN3266-impacted trailer and swept them in with hand tools. All soda ash and the damaged drum were placed into one (1) 85-gallon drum for disposal.

THE PACKAGE WAS NEUTRALIZED WITH SODIUM BICARBONATE AND THEN ABSORBED WITH ZEP ZORBANT.

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-29
  • City: BROCKWAY
  • State: PA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLI TRANSPORT, LP
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Our tanker vehicle loaded full with 87 Gasoline was struck by another vehicle. Our trailer required to be towed. Before it was towed the damaged trailer was emptied by a third party company with a pumping truck, into an empty secondary tanker we had brought onto location. In the events of the pumping truck transferring the product, the pumping company did not verify that all of the product was transferred from one tank of the damaged truck to the corresponding tank of the new truck. In doing so, our 1100 gallon tank was overfilled and 20 gallons of gasoline was pushed out of the vapor recovery line on our trailer. The third party company used absorbent mats, brooms, absorbent socks, and clean up powder to mitigate the effects of the release.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: New England Disposal Technologies was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 2ft-by-4ft area of the trailer floor and a 1ft-by-3ft area of concrete underneath the trailer and estimated that eight (8) cups of material was released due to the valve being semi open. New England Disposal Technologies personnel neutralized the impacted areas and deployed absorbents. The remaining material in the leaking tote was transferred to a new tote. The leaking tote and recovered material were cut up and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon poly drums for disposal.

Clean Harbors personnel deployed absorbents and then swept up the released material. The damaged drums were overpacked into three (3) 95-gallon poly drums. The recovered material and spent absorbents were placed into three (3) 55-gallon metal drums and two (2) 30-gallon poly drums and were staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

item.title: Report E-2024070417
item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2024-07-19T18:15:23+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-06-26
  • City: GARDEN CITY
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO- XDE contacted ERTS regarding a leaking 250-gallon metal tote containing hazardous product, Zinc Octoate 8%. A Contractor discovered that the lid to the tote was loose and likely the cause of the release. It was estimated that 5-gallons of product spilled from the lid impacting the metal tote itself, the wooden trailer floor, and the steel grate on trailer floor. The total impact are was estimated to be 6’x6’. The Contractor was able to tighten the lid and perform a slosh test confirming that adjustments made to the lid were successful and the tote is in proper working order to ship on to the Consignee. One 55-gallon DM was generated for waste disposal containing impacted cardboard, PPE, and absorbent pads/rags. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident

Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 4ft-by-4ft area of the trailer floor and estimated that three (3) quarts of material was released due to the boxes being crushed during transit. HEPACO personnel verified four (4) boxes were damaged. HEPACO deployed oil dri and swept up the released material. The damaged product and recovered material was placed into two (2) 55-gallon poly drums and was staged onsite at the terminal prior to the contractor demobilization.

  • Description: It was reported that approximately 50-gallons of Spectrum 22 released from one (1) 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS reviewed the SDS and dispatched HEPACO to assist with cleanup. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 40ft-by-10ft area of the trailer floor and asphalt underneath the trailer and estimated that fifty (50) gallons of material was released due to an unknown reason from one (1) 330-gallon tote. The fire department was on site and blocking the spill with absorbents. HEPACO personnel transferred the remaining material in the tote to vented poly drums. HEPACO thoroughly cleaned all impacted surfaces. The waste and damaged tote was containerized into poly drums for disposal.

  • Description: It was reported that approximately 100-gallons of Sulfuric acid released from one (1) 275-gallon tote onto the trailer floor and asphalt underneath the trailer. The Tote was punctured on the bottom by a forklift during unloading, releasing to the trailer interior and onto the dock and parking lot. ERTS dispatched Hepaco to the site to assist with clean up. The contractor arrived on-site and confirmed the product affected a 20’x4’ area on the trailer floor and underneath the trailer floor. The contractor collected and containerized the Dilute Sulfuric Acid (35%) and all clean-up debris into six (6) 55-gallon drums and one (1) 275-gallon tote. All waste was stored onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While unloading, one 2,450Ib tote was discovered leaking. Area was isolated and contractor was dispatched. GrayMar Environmental responded to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, GrayMar Environmental inspected the leaking tote and determined the cap was faulty, which resulted in the release of approximately 0.5 gallon of product. Free product released to trailer floor and dock at customer location. GrayMar Environmental used absorbent material and rags to wipe the area clean, and transferred the leaking tote into a recovery tote to be sent on to the consignee. One 55-gallon drum of spent absorbent and cleanup debris was generated during the cleanup. Product was contained to an impervious surface and did not impact soil or threaten to impact state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-30
  • City: FORT MYERS
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: PEPSI BOTTLING COMPANY LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While reversing into dock area at PepsiCo facility, vehicle struck another truck in lot, which damaged the saddle tank. Approximately 20 gallons of Diesel fuel were released to the asphalt surface and a minimal amount migrated to the nearby storm drain. PepsiCo personnel contained the release, and ACT Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, ACT Environmental applied absorbent material to the affected asphalt and inspected the nearby storm drain. Absorbent pads were utilized within storm drain catch basin to soak free product, and no further residual remained. Product was contained to the storm drain catch basin and did not migrate through drainage system. All spent absorbent material and pads were recovered and containerized into one 55-gallon drum, pending disposal in accordance with local, state, and federal regulations. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. During delivery, the vent line failed, which resulted in the release of approximately 50 gallons of gasoline to the asphalt parking lot and nearby storm drain. The Local Fire Department responded to assess and applied absorbent material to contain the release. First Call Environmental was dispatched to perform the cleanup. Upon arrival on site, First Call Environmental applied additional absorbent material, which was worked in and recovered. First Call Environmental utilized a drum vacuum to recover the free product from the storm drain catch basin, and confirmed product was contained to catch basin and did not migrate through the sewer system. Two 55-gallon drums of spent absorbent material were generated during the cleanup. There was no impact to soils or threat to state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On Thursday, 05/02/2024, at approximately 5:25am ET. Standard Petroleum's driver was ' traveling on the 1-95 - southbound in the right lane (of3). As Standard Petroleum's driver approached exit 14 on 1-95 southbound, a black Chevy Camaro struck Standard Petroleum's upper right side as the Camaro driver crossed a solid white line when it merged into traffic. After striking Standard Petroleum's vehicle, the Camaro then struck a trailer traveling parallel to Standard Petroleum m the middle lane, which caused the trailer to strike Standard Petroleum's vehicle. The cause of the failure is still being investigated; however, it is Standard Petroleum s understanding that the trailer struck Standard Petroleum's fuel tank which caused a fuel leak. Since the investigation is ongoing, Standard Petroleum is not able to describe the package failure with specificity at this time. ?nee Standard Petroleum's driver discovered the fuel leak, he immediately called 911 and notified Stand ard Petroleum dispatch of the incident. It is Standard Petroleum's unders!anding that either DEEP or Connecticut State Police notified Standard Republic, who is an environmental first responder for the State of Connecticut, to remedy the fuel leak.

  • Description: On 6/07/2024, the Delta Dangerous Goods management team was notified of an undeclared shipment of 2 non-spillable, wet batteries secured to the back bed of two new golf carts. The golf carts did not contain any fluids (oils, fuels), however, the non-spillable wet batteries were removed/disconnected from the battery compartment and placed/strapped to the aft bed of the cart. There was not a shipping paper associated with the batteries. This event is under immediate investigation.
